job_title: Administrative Assistant in La Crosse, WI
pros: Everyone is nice! Free college for you and your children. Week off paid for Christmas. Lots of community involvement.
cons: Pay. Since it is a private Catholic school the pay is almost minimum wage.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Crosse, WI
pros: Not many. They claim to have values and plaster posters all over the place professing their values. But, it is more of a marketing scheme than a legitimate possession of values. The posters appeal to parents who are unknowingly bringing their students to a low-quality institution, and they appeal to prospective employees who are unaware of the mismanaged institution that they will work for.
cons: Flip-flopping leadership - back and forth - back and forth. Instructors who are minimally qualified and out-of-date with current trends in their fields. Lack of professional development. Deceptive practices. LOW pay. LOW morale. Struggling with maintaining enrollment. Degree mill. Students have been awarded grades of A's for classes that instructors forgot to teach. Students not adequately prepared to enter the workforce. Lacks diversity. Discriminatory and biased educational approach.

pros: Some faculty and staff are really nice. However, there is little room for advancement and professional growth. Enrollment issues and high turnover increased my administrative duties and my research agenda suffered. Moved onto a university with healthier enrollment and more faculty resources for research and professional growth. This is a great place for a person fresh out of grad school. Low marks for programmatic instability, high turnover, and overall institutional financial concerns.
cons: High turnover. Low pay. Low enrollment. Program instability. No professional growth opportunities. Not a great place for a serious research professor.

pros: Benefits are great! They also have tuition remission benefits as well!
cons: Pay is not good. You work long hours for little pay.

pros: Strong mission-driven institution with sense of community
cons: Lack of work-life balance Faces challenges that most higher education institutions currently do

job_title: Physical Plant in La Crosse, WI
cons: Senior administrators are not very nice

job_title: Marketing Coordinator in La Crosse, WI
pros: Walkable location, big offices, friendly staff,

review_title: Awful - LOW morale - The worst place to work
pros: Not much. Employees bond over low pay and lack of advancement opportunities.
cons: So many cons. Low pay, NO pay raises, low morale. Departments are pitted against one another. Lack of diversity. Underlying bias, racism, and anti-LGBTQ. A tiny college trying to act like a large one - it's actually more like a high school with ashtrays. Constant turnover in administration and restructuring of the college structure equates to constant flux. Education is not modern, rather it's reminiscent of 1970. Food is gross and cleanliness of facilities is lacking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Crosse, WI
pros:
-Follows core values (contemplation, hospitality, integrity, service, stewardship)
-Ample vacation and sick leave

cons:
-Lots of library staff leaving. Toxic/bullying environment

job_title: Assistant Professor in La Crosse, WI
pros: People are nice, small enough you get to know a lot of people pretty quickly
cons: You end up lighting yourself on fire to keep people warm- always expected to take on more, and no one really cares about how badly we are overloaded

review_title: Only care about numbers, not people.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Crosse, WI
pros: Not really any pros, honestly. People leave for a reason.
cons: I have never witnessed such poor leadership. Terrible culture- it's not true what they say about their culture being great. It's about money, not helping employees succeed or be happy.

review_title: A good place to work for environment and benefits
job_title: Project Coordinator in La Crosse, WI

review_title: Small college with a medium sized feel
job_title: Assistant Softball Coach in La Crosse, WI
pros: Small campus and great relationships within the classroom
cons: Lacking in diversity and a little behind with policies

job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Crosse, WI
pros: Viterbo is a small, close-knit community.  Probably the biggest perk to working at Viterbo is the tuition remission program for employees, spouses, and dependent children.
cons: I attended Viterbo University as a student, and I thoroughly enjoyed my experience.  I enjoyed it so much that after graduation it became my goal to come back and work for Viterbo.  After working at Viterbo for a while, I am terribly disillusioned and disappointed.  The theme of servant leadership that inspired me as a student, translates into being taken advantage of as an employee.  Let me explain.  As an employee, servant leadership entails being paid below average for my job field, being overworked, and being underappreciated.  Viterbo currently has no leave donation program.

job_title: Associate Professor in La Crosse, WI
pros: Generally collegial and hospitable atmosphere; strong emphasis on teaching and service; relatively easy to achieve promotion and tenure; most students capable of college-level work; work-life balance acceptable after 5+ years.
cons: Emphasis on flagship professional programs (nursing, business, education, fine arts) challenges liberal arts foundation; salaries below average; little green space on campus; very limited opportunities to conduct research; faculty expected to devote time to recruitment; work-life balance poor during first several years.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in La Crosse, WI
pros: Everyone is very welcoming! The president is very engaged with students, staff, visitors. Free college for you and children and spouses. The week between Christmas and New Years we get off.
cons: Low pay rate. Faculty seems to be more a focus than the other staff. Not much room for advancement since a small university.

pros: You feel like you're part of a family, working at Viterbo. Great sharing between departments. Your individual skills and talents are encouraged and there are plenty ways to keep you challenged.
cons: The pay and upward mobility could be better. Although those could be the general challenges of any smaller private university.

job_title: Admission Counselor in La Crosse, WI
pros: Tuition remission and vacation  offerings are a  huge plus, and my co-workers are supportive.
cons: There's no way to work up the ladder,   it's hard to feel heard by management, and you have to fight for fair wages and raises.
